column1: # all data from Ellegard 1953, much of it re-reported in Kroch 1989 where it
# formed the basis of the 'Constant Rate Hypothesis'/'Constant Rate Effect'.
# "Of the curves, the one for negative questions is the most irregular one. This
# is probably due above all to the relatively small number of instances which
# exposes the samples to chance variations. The humps on the curve for negative
# declarative sentences should however be regarded as significant. The low
# figure for 1625-1650 is probably due to the non-colloquial nature of some of
# table 7 on p.161: affirmative declaratives, negative declaratives, negative
# questions and negative imperatives (affirmative questions are also reported
# but the counts are broken down in more detail in a later table, see below)
# breakdown of these counts into transitive vs. intransitive in table 16, p.196:
# Negative imperatives, not considered in Kroch 1989, but in Ogura 1993
# table 19 (p.203): affirmative wh & yes/no questions, by (in)transitivity
# a different view on the same data: affirmative questions broken down by type:
# "we should therefore expect the do-form to be relatively more frequent in
# those questions where the simple verb form had to be followed by both subject
# and object. In the first place, do should be less frequent in questions with
# the object placed at the head (object questions, o: what said he?), in the
# second place, it should be less frequent in adverb-questions, a (when came
# he?) and verb-questions, v (went he?), when the verb was intransitive" (p.202)
